questions.question: In thin layer chromatography (TLC), why is it essential to ensure that the stationary phase is fully dried before analysing the results?

answers.b: To reduce the polarity of the stationary phase.
answers.c: To enhance the separation of ink components.
answers.d: Drying the stationary phase is not necessary.

questions.question: What is the Rf value in the context of TLC?

answers.a: The rate of flow of the stationary phase.
answers.b: The distance travelled by the solvent.
answers.c: The ratio of the distance travelled by a component to the distance travelled by the solvent front.

questions.question: Why is it important to experiment with solvents of varying polarities when performing TLC?

answers.a: To increase the thickness of the stationary phase.
answers.b: To reduce the distance travelled by the solvent front.
answers.c: To determine the Rf values of the components.
answers.d: To find a suitable solvent for separating or identifying components.

questions.question: If a solvent with very high polarity is used in TLC, what is the likely outcome?

answers.c: No separation will occur as all components will move with the solvent.
answers.d: Solvent front will not reach the top of the TLC plate.

questions.question: What characteristic of different ink components make their identification possible using TLC?

answers.d: Their unique Rf values in specific solvents.
